Message.Title: Downloading To A Spreadsheet ?
Message.Msg: Hello, Have used Yahoo Finance to list my stocks in a modest portfolio. Really neat. Question, please: I tried to "Download", via their option selection the listings and columns to an Excel Spreadsheet. It seems to download as a .csv, and not as the default (I think) normal Excel format. Why ? And, pretty much just gibberish. The stocks are all there, but shares, prices, etc seem to show as ###, or other nonsense. What might I be doing wrong, as usual, please ? I thought that whatever "View" was showing would be the one downloaded as a normal Excel Spreadsheet, but apparently not ? Any help with this would be very appreciated. Sr. Citizen now, and some of this "stuff" isn't as easy as it once was. BTW: as I'm just getting started, let me ask the following, which I hope doesn't upset anyone: Why do you use Yahoo Finance rather than Google Finance ? Pros and Cons ? Thanks, Bob

Message.Title: Yahoo Mail complements Dropbox integration with direct Flickr photo sharing
Message.Msg: Yahoo today announced it has integrated Flickr directly Yahoo Mail. Users of the company’s mail service can now share individual photos or sets without leaving their inbox. “Not only is it simple to share as many Flickr photos as you’d like, but they’re displayed in a beautiful way, just like they are on Flickr itself,” Yahoo says. Here’s how the integration looks (ever since the company’s Tumblr acquisition, it demonstrates everything as a GIF): To take advantage of this new functionality, first make sure you are logged into Flickr. Next, from Yahoo Mail, click the arrow next to the paperclip and choose “Share from Flickr.” All of your photos are available right there. In early April, Dropbox announced full integration with Yahoo Mail, letting email users send, receive, and manage attachments. The idea was to offer a workaround for the size limitations of email attachments, and especially since both Google and Microsoft already offer their own solutions to the problem (SkyDrive and Drive, respectively). Photos are arguably the most popular and often the largest types of files that are shared via email. With the addition of 1TB of storage to Flickr last month, it makes a lot of sense to let Yahoo Mail users take advantage as well. It also doesn’t hurt to add an advertisement for Yahoo Mail users who aren’t on Flickr yet. “Not a Flickr user? No problem, you can sign up without leaving Mail.” Yahoo says more “helpful features” are on the way to Mail. Unfortunately, the company didn’t drop any other hints nor suggest when they might arrive. We’ll keep you posted either way.

Topic.Title: Former Alibaba Exec (David Wei) Puts Alibaba Group IPO Value at $100 Billion

Message.Msg: Speaking more broadly about where Alibaba might list, a question that remains undecided according to the company, Mr. Wei said that Hong Kong has ample liquidity and would give Alibaba strong exposure to international investors.‬ ‪On the other hand, he pointed out that U.S. markets have a better understanding of tech companies.‬‪ He concluded that if Alibaba wishes to emphasize the commerce component of its business, it will list in Hong Kong, if it wishes to highlight the technology side, it will list in the U.S.‬
